messages.content: LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
3 types of AI Tik Tok

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

A problem with AI today is that it means different things to different people. 

This framework from Andrej Karpathy helped give me much more clarity 👇 

Software 1.0 = Rule-based software systems. Humans program computers to solve problems step-by-step. 

Software 2.0 = Computers program themselves by seeing examples (i.e. machine learning) 

Software 3.0 = Repurposing general-purpose ML models for specific use cases (i.e. GenAI + Foundation Models) 

But… what’s Software 4.0 going to be? 🤔

--

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Challenges of fine-tuning on Mac. Promote YouTube video

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Nvidia is making it not a great time to be a Mac user... 

While fine-tuning ML models has never been easier, most of the open-source tooling is built for Nvidia hardware. 

This means many Mac users (like me) have watched Windows and Linux users from the sidelines when it comes to fine-tuning models locally 🙍🏻‍♂️💻 

That was until I discovered the MLX Python library! 

In my latest YouTube video, I walk through a simple way to fine-tune Mistral 7b to respond to my YT comments using a Mac Mini (M1 16GB) 

👉 Check it out here: https://lnkd.in/g6zCH-Hr

--

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Mistake from previous fine-tuning blog and sharing new one

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Last year, I wrote a popular blog on fine-tuning LLMs with example code. 

There was only one problem… my fine-tuned model was overfitting 🤦🏻‍♂️ 

While it doesn't feel so good to be wrong publicly (32k people read that article), it's one of the best ways to learn. 

Public mistakes are great motivators for improvement and are an effective way of internalizing lessons. 

One year later, I’ve (finally) redeemed myself by sharing another fine-tuning example (that doesn’t overfit). 

I break down the example code in my latest blog post on fine-tuning BERT for text classification. 

Check it out and let me know if I missed anything else 😅

 https://lnkd.in/gc7rHDap 

P.S. Thanks to 🚀 Jeremy ARANCIO for pointing out the mistake in the original blog post ❤️

--

LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Lessons from mentorship call with $100k/mo entrepreneur

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Last month, I booked my most expensive mentorship call yet at $700/hr 😬 

While this might sound like a big number, the person on the other side of the call makes $100k/mo as a solo AI entrepreneur. 

Here are my key takeaways from this conversation... 

1) Focus on customer pain points and problems, not your past experience and skills. 

2) Price for the customer's value, not your time. 

3) The bigger the price tag, the longer the copy (i.e. delay the ask) 

4) Get hyper-clear on the customer and their problem, then attract them with free content (on socials) and a lead magnet. 

5) The difference between 10k/mo and 100k/mo is more often business strategy rather than technical expertise. 

Although these points might be Business 101 for some, many technical founders (like me) never learned these basics. 

This is great news because it means I can probably get significant gains from a few simple adjustments. 

Super grateful to Jason Liu for taking the time to share his wisdom with me 🙏

--

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Sharing LLM compression blog post

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Large language models (LLMs) demonstrate impressive performance across a wide range of tasks. 

However, their immense scale can make deploying them in real-world settings a challenge 😮‍💨 

In my latest blog post, I discuss how to mitigate these challenges using model compression. 

Model compression seeks to reduce an ML model’s size without sacrificing performance. 

I review 3 types of compression techniques (i.e. Quantization, Pruning, and Knowledge Distillation) and walk through an example implementation in Python. 

Check it out and let me know what you think 👇

--

Today, a 7B parameter model can be (efficiently) fine-tuned on a single GPU! 

However, Mac users have been largely left out of this trend due to Apple’s M-series chips (i.e. no GPUs) 😷 💻 ... 

I had almost given up on my dreams of training LLMs locally until I discovered the MLX Python library. 

In my latest blog post, I walk through an easy way to fine-tune Mistral 7B locally on my Mac Mini (M1 16GB).

Thanks to Towards Data Science for publishing 😁

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
sharing 2 helpful textbook on LLMs and AI

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Although there are more learning resources for AI and ML than ever before, finding high-quality ones can still be a challenge. 

Here are two I’m working through now 👇 

1) Super Study Guide: Transformers & Large Language Models conceptually builds LLMs from the ground up. 

It also has many incredible visualizations that help clarify (the many 😅) abstract mathematical concepts in ML. 

2) Building LLMs for Production is a LLM practitioner’s guidebook. 

This is the most comprehensive reference I’ve seen on actually building things with LLMs. 

Thanks to Afshine Amidi, Shervine Amidi, Louis-François Bouchard, and Louie Peters for taking the time to distill your knowledge into these incredible resources 😁

--

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
3 ways to make LLMs multimodal and sharing blog post

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Over the past year, we’ve seen LLMs gain the ability to see (i.e. process images) and hear (i.e. process audio directly), but how does that work under the hood? 

Here are 3 general ways to do that 👇 

1. LLM + Tools: Augment LLMs with pre-built components 

2. LLM + Adapters: Augment LLMs with multi-modal encoders or decoders, which are aligned via adapter fine-tuning 

3. Unified Models: Expand LLM architecture to fuse modalities at pre-training 

In my latest blog post in Towards Data Science, I discuss these three approaches and share example code for (locally) using LLaMA 3.2 Vision to perform various image-to-text tasks. 

Check it out here: https://lnkd.in/gGcvVk9u

--

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Explaining multimodal embeddings and sharing blog post

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Although text and images may look very different to us, to a neural network, these are represented via the same mathematical object, i.e., a vector. 

Therefore, we can image vector spaces where text and images look similar, given they represent the same underlying information. 

This is the key idea behind multimodal embeddings. 

In my latest blog post, I share how we can generate such representations along with two practical use cases for them: 1) 0-shot Image Classification and 2) Image search. 

Check it out here 👇 https://lnkd.in/g-Dvy9dF

--

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Importance of deploying ML models and a simple way to do it. Share blog post

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Although it may seem that machine learning is all about training fancy models, in the real world, a model (by itself) does NOT generate value. 

To turn an ML model into an ML solution (i.e., something valuable), we must “deploy it.” 

While this can take many different forms, there is a simple 3-step strategy that works well in many situations…

Step 1: Create an inference API 

Step 2: Containerize the API 

Step 3: Run the container on a cloud platform 

👉 In a recent Towards Data Science article, I break down how to implement this 3-step strategy using FastAPI, Docker, and GCP. 

Check it out and let me know what you think 👇

--

LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Lessons from 13 months of entrepreneurship

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

It’s been 13 months since I had a W2 job... 

During this time, I’ve realized there are several popular misconceptions about entrepreneurship. 

Here are a few that are top of mind for me right now 👇 

❌ "I need funding to build a business." 
✅ The vast majority of businesses take no outside funding, and <1% take VC. Figuring out how to survive IS the game. 

❌ "I need an idea that can scale well." 
✅ ”Do things that don’t scale” -Paul Graham. There’s no point in scaling something no one wants. IF demand exists, then there’s always a way to scale. 

❌ "I need to learn web development frameworks to build a SaaS product." 
✅ ”Build with the tech you know” -Peiter Levels. The key is speed. You don’t have six months to take a bootcamp. Learn what you need to solve the problem.

--
Media: Image
LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Advice for data people thinking of pursuing entrepreneurship

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Last year, I passed on a $150k data science promotion to pursue my entrepreneurial dream life. Here’s my honest advice for data people considering a similar transition 👇 

1) Start with a side hustle 

Making money as an entrepreneur is very different than getting a paycheck. A side hustle is a great, low-stakes way to develop the necessary skillset. 

The way I got started was through content creation and freelancing. 

2) Learn how to sell 

Data people typically have high-value skills like programming, data analytics, and machine learning. However, having these skills is not sufficient for monetizing them. 

For that, you need to figure out how to sell yourself and your offers. 

3) Shift your mindset from “What job can I do?” to “What problems can I solve?” 

This is one of the biggest mindset shifts I’ve had to make this past year. 

Focusing on fulfilling a role means you will always need someone's permission to get paid (whether a manager or a client). 

However, when you focus on solving problems, there are very few constraints on how you can generate value, so you can make a living on your terms.

--
Media: Image
LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
3 habits I had to break to become a senior data scientist

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Here are 3 habits I had to BREAK before becoming a Senior Data Scientist 👇 

1) Not digging deeper ❌ 

Something that took me too long to learn was the importance of asking “why?” and digging more deeply into a request to find the underlying problem. 

2) Focusing on technologies instead of problems ❌ 

As a technical person, I found it easy to get so caught up in fancy new technologies that the problem we were trying to solve took a back seat. 

3) Seeking sophistication ❌ 

My favorite part of data science is combining techniques in creative ways to solve problems. 

However, this can lead to overly sophisticated solutions that can often be replaced by simpler ones while still capturing the value. 

👉 What’s a key lesson you’ve learned on your journey?

--

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
How to build client relationships as a data scientist

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

To be an effective data scientist focus on relationships, not technologies. 

While data science requires a minimum amount of technical proficiency, this isn’t the usual bottleneck for a data team’s impact 💥 

The more I’ve worked with clients on business use cases, the more I’ve realized how a shallow relationship and lack of trust can hinder a data project’s impact. 

Here are 3 things I do to cultivate a new client relationship 👇 

1) Be curious (about the problem and where the other side is coming from) 

2) Be transparent (about the limits of my skills and knowledge) 

3) Be myself (don’t try to put up a front—it’s unsustainable) 

Anything I can add here? 🤔

--

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Lesson from posting 1 Youtube video a week

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Last quarter, I did an experiment where I posted 1 YouTube video every week. 

... it did not go as expected 😬 

My Hypothesis—Since YouTube drives 80% of my inbound traffic (e.g., paid calls, speaking gigs, project opportunities), doubling my video output will double my business. 

The Results—Almost every business metric went down e.g. number of paid calls, number of leads, subscribers per month, YT revenue per month 😅 

So what happened? 

My (current) guesses: 

- No LLM videos (these are among my most popular) 
- Less time per video diminished quality 
- I spent too much time making content and not enough time talking to clients and other folks working in the space (i.e. I got out of touch) 

That’s why this quarter, I’ll be scaling back my content quantity and focusing more on quality by… 

- Lowering my monthly YT video goal to 3 per month 
- Lowering my consultation rates (so I can stay connected with people’s needs) 
- Doing more project work as an intellectual break from making videos

--
Media: Image

👉 In my latest YouTube video, I discuss these points in greater detail and do a hands-on walkthrough of a project I’ve been working on to implement semantic search over my YouTube videos.

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Why entrepreneurs shouldn’t quit, showcasing data and Lindy principle

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

You often hear entrepreneurs say, “keep going” or “just don’t quit” 

Here’s (statistically) why this is good advice 👇 

The 1st plot below shows business survival rates est in 1994 up until 2023 

This demonstrates the low odds of entrepreneurial success, with 50% closing after 5 years. 

However, something interesting happens if we look at this same curve for businesses that have been around for a few years (2nd plot). 

Here, we see the curve incrementally move up the longer a business stays alive. 

In other words, their probability of survival increases the longer they survive 📈 

For example, although only 50% of new businesses make it to year 5, these odds jump to 57% after just 1 year in business! 

So this is a reminder to all the entrepreneurs out there… keep going. 

Each day you survive, your odds of success go up a little bit 💪

--
Media: Charts
LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Getting a data science job was hard until I learned these 5 things

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Getting a Data Science Job was hard until I learned these 5 things 👇 

1. Adapt your resume to the specific role 

You have about 7 seconds of a hiring manager's attention when reviewing your resume; use it to call out all the skills they listed in the job description. 

2. Do real-world projects 

While toy projects from class or Kaggle are a great way to learn, hiring managers care about real-world impact. 

3. Make a portfolio 

Despite the free no-code tools for making a portfolio website, most people don't make one. That makes this a super easy way to stand out. 

4. Stay out of the weeds (unless they ask) 

This was one of my greatest struggles. When someone asked about a project, I would dive right into the technical details. 

This is the best way to lose someone's attention (even data scientists). 

5. Be yourself (not who you think they want to hire) 

When I interviewed for my full-time data science role, I dove into a rant about my love for optimization. 

Most people get confused and awkward when I discuss such topics, but not the interviewers. They got pumped up... that's when I knew I found my people 😁 

What was an unlock for you when applying to data science roles?

--

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
AI won’t make you rich… solving problems will

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

AI won’t make you rich… solving problems will. 

Over the past year, I’ve seen a trend of CEOs and founders scrambling to find AI use cases for their businesses. 

While this AI excitement is great for data scientists like me, it is not sufficient for value generation. 

In other words, “using AI” won’t necessarily move the needle on the things important to businesses. 

For that, one must solve problems… which may not require a chatbot, RAG system, or any state-of-the-art AI model. 

More often than not, using readily available AI assistants (e.g., ChatGPT) and having good data infrastructure will get businesses 80% there.

Therefore, building a robust agent (i.e., not a prototype) is still an expensive and non-trivial engineering problem ❌ 

However, there is another technology that enables the development of simpler and cheaper AI systems while still capturing much of the value. 

I’m talking about Text Embeddings 😮 In my latest YouTube video, I give a beginner-friendly introduction to text embeddings and share 2 relatively simple (yet high-value) use cases.

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Don’t build a chatbot and 5 LLM use case ideas.

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Don’t use AI to build a chatbot 🤖 

❌ Although ChatGPT (and friends) has captured the world’s imagination regarding AI, the business value of building an "AI chatbot" may not justify the cost. 

Here are 5 better LLM use cases for business 👇 

1) Structure unstructured data—format data from inconvenient sources into a structured database 

2) Standardize data—resolve conflicts between databases and make it analytics-ready 

3) Data augmentation—enrich existing datasets with meta-tags and other information 

4) Data generation—create synthetic datasets for developing custom AI solutions 

5) Semantic search—improve existing search functions using text embeddings 🤔 

What am I missing here? 

#LLM #AI #datascience

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Importance of problem discovery for data scientists and sharing blog post

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Data science is more than just training fancy machine learning models. 

When you boil it down, the ultimate goal is to solve problems. 

Since, as data scientists, we typically don’t solve our own problems, the ability to communicate and learn from stakeholders is a critical skill set. 

👉 In my latest article, I lay out 5 “problem discovery” questions that every data scientist should hardcode into their brain. 

These questions are the product of 10 interviews with seasoned data freelancers on their approach to these conversations and 25 discovery calls of my own. 

Here’s the list 👇 

What problem are you trying to solve? 
Why...? 
What’s your dream outcome? 
What have you tried so far? 
Why me? 

Anything to add? 🤔 

#datascience #consulting #freelance

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
10 AI buzzwords explained

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

AI seems to be riddled with buzzwords these days. 

Here are 10 common AI terms every practitioner should know... 

1) RAG = automatically providing relevant context (i.e. docs) to an AI system so it can generate better responses
2) Vector DB = numerical representations of documents which can be used for RAG and search 
3) Fine-tuning = adapting a model to a particular use case through additional training 
4) AI Agent = an AI system that can plan and execute tasks 
5) Evals = tests that score an AI system’s efficacy 
6) Hallucination = a "made-up" response from an AI that sounds reasonable 
7) Multimodal = data of different formats (e.g. text, images, audio, videos, tables, time series) 
8) Small Language Models = LLMs with ~1B parameters 
9) Quantization = reducing the precision of model parameters to reduce its size 
10) Distillation = using a large model to train a smaller one 

—

 What's missing from this list?

--

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
5 AI projects you can build this weekend

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

The best way to learn AI is by building projects… but what do I build? 

Here are 5 AI project ideas you can implement this weekend (with Python). 

1. Resume Optimization (Beginner) 👨🏻‍💼 

Use OpenAI’s Python API to adapt your resume to specific job descriptions. 

Lib: openai 

2. YouTube Lecture Summarizer (Beginner) 🎥 

Take those (long) ML lectures collecting dust in your "watch later", and summarize them to see if they're worth keeping around. 

Libs: openai, youtube-transcript-api 

3. Automatically Organizing PDFs (Intermediate) 📄 

If you’re like me and have an unreasonable number of unread research papers (118) on your desktop, you can build a tool to generate text embeddings for each file and use a simple clustering algorithm to organize them into folders. 

Libs: sentence_transformers, sklearn 

4. Multimodal Semantic Search (Intermediate) 🔍 

Searching text is easy… but what about videos and images? Now, you can use multimodal embedding models to embed text and images in the same space for search. 

Libs: transformers Model: nomic-ai/nomic-embed-text-v1.5 

5. Desktop QA (Advanced) 💬 

You can connect a multimodal knowledge base to a model like Llama-3.2-11B-Vision to do question-answering. 

Libs: transformers, together (Llama-3.2-vision is free until 2025) 

Drop a comment if you want me to flesh any of these out 👇

--

LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
How I’d learn AI if I started over today.

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

AI has changed a lot since I started 5 years ago. 

Here’s how I’d learn it if I had to start over… 

1. Learn Python 

Although some say you don’t need to learn to code anymore, I still think it’s essential for anyone who wants to build custom software solutions. 

2. Build Projects 

The AI space is too massive and evolving too quickly to effectively learn from a textbook. The best approach (IMO) is to start by building projects and learning concepts as needed. 

3. Start with Kaggle/HF Datasets 

While you’ll never find neatly curated data in the real world, I think using resources like Kaggle or Hugging Face is a great starting place for beginners. 

Some libraries worth learning for this initial project are: Pandas (or Polars), matplotlib, and sklearn 

4. Find a real-world project 

After one or two toy projects, it’s time to start working on something more practical. 

The best projects solve a real-world problem. I’d seek one out by reaching out to businesses or other orgs in my network to see if I could offer them free work. 

5. Use ChatGPT and Cursor 

AI coding assistants have become the norm for programming. Use them to help you learn faster and get you unblocked as needed.

--
